summary: MERS-CoV is associated with high fatality rates (3, 4), and cases have increased to 909 laboratory-confirmed cases with 331 fatalities. MERS-CoV is the second emerging CoV with severe pathogenicity in humans within 10 years after the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) that infected approximately 8,000 people worldwide during its spread in 2003. the unusual tropism of MERS-CoV has been related to the wide tissue distribution of DPP4 on renal epithelial cells or leukocytes. innate immunity and IFN secretion are critical parameters for the outcome of MERS-CoV infection. pDCs produced large amounts of IFN- and IFN- and moderate amounts of IFN- upon contact with MERS-CoV without virus amplification. the observed IFN induction was dependent on the availability of the MERS-CoV receptor DPP4, endosomal maturation, or partially on PAMP recognition via toll-like receptor 7 (TLR7) MERS-CoV (EMC/2012) (14) and SARS-CoV (27) were propagated in vero cells. titters were determined by 50% tissue culture infection dose (TCID50) titration on vero cells. 2 105 CD14+ monocytes were cultured in 96-well flat-bottom tissue culture plates using X-VIVO 15 medium (Lonza) for generation of GM-CSF-derived macrophages, monocytes were cultured in RPMI 1640 medium containing 10% FBS, 10 mM l-glutamine, 0.5 mM penicillin-streptomycin (PAA Laboratories, Egelsbach, Germany), 0.1 mM pDCs were seeded at a density of 2 104 pDCs/well in 96-well plates. pDCs were generated from bone marrow cells isolated from femurs and tibias of sacrificed 6- to 10-week-old C57BL/6N mice. pDCs were seeded at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0.01 or 5. supernatants of human cells were analyzed using a human IFN- or mouse IFN- ELISA (R&D Systems), human IL-29 (IFN-1) ELISA (eBioscience, Frankfurt, Germany), or a human IL-6 DuoSet ELISA development system (R&D Systems) pDCs were preincubated for 30 min at 37°C were converted to x-fold ratios. cells were lysed at the indicated time points and subjected to analyses. expression of MERS-CoV nucleocapsid protein in infected human pDCs. no coV N protein was detected in murine pDCs at 1 hpi. primary human pDCs produce large amounts of type I and type III IFNs in response to MERS-CoV infection. secretion of IFNs was exclusively found in pDCs (25), but the amounts of IFNs induced by MERS-CoV were significantly higher. chloroquine is an inhibitor of endosomal maturation and can inhibit IFN production induced by viruses (e.g., HIV) via PRRs within the endosome (46). the pattern of IFN- secretion by human pDCs after MERS-CoV inoculation followed that of IFN-, as expected. transmembrane protease serine 2 (TMPRSS2) has been shown to be responsible for cleavage during MERS-CoV entry into Calu-3 cells (49). lysosomal proteases such as cathepsin L are required to activate the MERS-CoV S protein (50), but their activity depends on endosomal maturation (51) a model explaining the mechanism how of MERS-CoV induces type I IFN in human pDCs may be proposed. a model explaining the mechanism how of MERS-CoV induces type I IFN in human pDCs may be proposed. this absence of significant MERS-CoV replication in pDCs is explained by the significant (biological and functional) differences between pDCs and other DC subsets. the figure schematically depicts the life cycle of MERS-CoV in human pDCs. the release of type I and III IFNs may protect against MERS-CoV-induced pathogenicity. it is counterintuitive that MERS-CoV induces significantly higher secretion of IFNs than SARS-CoV when infecting pDCs. but clinically recorded MERS patients having a worse prognosis than SARS patients. enhanced IFN type I secretion upon MERS-CoV infection compared to SARS-CoV infection might hint at overshooting immune reactions.
